comments.body: I only agree with the first one, red nether bricks for fortresses sometimes.

I support having loot tables for woodland mansion storage rooms. Not high value items (diamond etc), but a nice selection of 'rare' building materials. It would be a slightly easier way for a player to get prismarine (for example) without having to take on a whole ocean monument.

@DarkElfLX adding prismarine doesn't fit super well with the style of Woodland Mansions, but it's still an interesting idea. Maybe illagers just like to collect rare building blocks and hoard them in their chests? I would be on board with that!

Flint and steel is very relevant to nether loot, since it’s necessary for someone trapped in the nether with an unlit portal.

In reality, are saddles and horse armor appropriate for any of the locations where they are found, except smithy chests?  I think it makes as much sense to leave them everywhere they currently are available as it does to remove them from specific areas.

@ClayGoddessSari We're starting to get into aesthetic (read: not objective) considerations here, but I'll explain why I wrote what I did. 

As far as the flint and steel goes, my thinking was that fire charges would be a better, more Nether-y, more dangerous alternative to flint and steel, since they also light portals. Also, let's be honest, fire charges could use the attention.

Your second point is a fair one, and one I struggled with too, but at the end of the day, for me, it boiled down to 1) There are horses in the Overworld but not the End or the Nether and 2) A Nether fortress often yields half an inventory's worth of horse equipment, which is an inventory-clutteringly high amount, compared to the more reasonable numbers you would get from any other structure.

I would agree with replacing flint and steel with fire charges.  I missed that aspect.

I will admit that I’m as much of a hoarder in video games as anyone, but technically there is nothing forcing you to pick up all that horse gear that you don’t want.  Personally, I’m also a hoarder of horses, so I want as much gear as I can get. X3

One problem I see with this is the loot for the nether. They should still have flint and steel, (iron), in the chest because if a gast blows up your portal, it would be nice to have a safe way back... Otherwise good idea!
Asbrae, thank you for the support, but read the comments, please. Fire charges can be used to light portals.
Lol, I guess I skipped over that one...

I think Jungle Temple chests should have vines as filler - those things are all over the place!

Also, Dungeon chests should have filler relevant to the mob spawner: Zombie Dungeons have rotten flesh while their Zombie Villager and Husk counterparts also have Emeralds and Sand, respectively; Skeleton Dungeons have bonemeal, bones, bows, arrows, and in the case of Strays, tipped arrows; and Spider Dungeons have cobwebs and string.

And why not have Ruins chests filled with sand and gravel? Those sediments get everywhere...

SupersuMC - the ruins and jungle temples ideas are excellent!! I do feel like the dungeon idea would require a overhaul of dungeon generation, though; besides, rotten flesh, bones, and string are all part of dungeon loot tables already.
Some way of converting wool to string would make sense. Maybe using a new thistle flower to tease it out.
endermen were once a human civilization, transformed to endermen to better survive the end.
My only suggestion is that there should be a low chance of Netherite scraps in the Fortress chests.

I support removing Horse Armor variants from Nether Fortress and End City loot chests, as they have no reason to be lying around in those dimensions. Horse Armor should be exclusive to overworld structures. Saddles can be removed from End City loot, but should remain in Nether Fortress loot as they are necessary to ride Striders.

To replace the removed loot possibilities, Nether Fortress chests could have a small chance of housing Netherite Scraps.
same goes for end city

Not only are the chests in the forest mansion empty, but if you restore a game from a backed up region file all the chests in all areas will disappear. They can only be made to reappear in 1.16.3 and 1.16.5 by flying into the chest in spectator mode, but in the latest snapshot that isn't possible. And of course, if they are restored in this way, they will be empty. As in, their loot tables will never trigger  and if players had items in them they won't be there either. This behavior needs to be fixed as well while they are at it.

Yeah, the woodland mansion one is important. All the empty chests feel like an unfinished feature, if they are meant to be storage rooms then add low-value items so that this is obvious. There could be bread, mushrooms, logs, planks, leather, or similar.
Changed the subject to be a little more specific and less confusing while searching. :)

This is a very good idea, we'll I think so atleast, and like you said " many people such as role-players builders and survivalists might like this idea too " and I am all those things. Just to prove your point!
I agree
That’s a really good idea and I need this in Minecraft

C'est une très bonne idée, j'aimerais beaucoup la voir dans Minecraft.

Chair is something that will boost building ideas for player which will encourage them to create building with creativity.

Adding even the most basic of furniture is something that's been needed for a long time. I'm a resource pack artist (privately, nothing submitted for distribution anywhere), and hate the idea of taking away from the choices of stairs to make a leather or cloth textured chair/couch section. And tables shouldn't *click* anytime you get too close (so annoying). I'd absolutely love to be able to texture the various wood chairs and tables into some really nice choices of furniture without taking away from the choices of stairs and other blocks that only vaguely approximate what I'm looking for. These simple things would go a long way in keeping players a little more centered on vanilla Minecraft without having to add mods to achieve what they want, and settling for any additional effects those mods might also add, but not necessarily be wanted.

Extra effects could also be afforded along with the new furniture. An added action of sitting in a chair in close proximity to a table could give a minor boost to any food eaten. Sitting with other players in one of a group of chairs with open space in the middle could auto-open chat for a conversation pit or planning meeting.
you should get craft them out of blocks to make modern or rustic furniture and there should be more things like couches and fancier beds and maybe even sleep on couches possibly them.
Is it just the villagers that can sit down or can it also be the player? Sorry just needed to make sure.
This is a good idea! I find my self bored and wanting something new to add to my creations.

Excellent Idea. There should be a whole variety of furniture options to fill out players’ buildings that are interactive. Instead of repurposing building materials to build make shift furniture that you can’t do anything with.

A huge appeal of Minecraft is constructing buildings and having actual pieces of furniture to decorate those buildings with would really increase the satisfaction and enjoyment of building in Minecraft.

Love the table and chair bit. This idea should also include 1x1 block statues as decorations. You could use them to create fountains or gargoyles on roofs. They don't all have to be creepers, skeletons, zombies, spiders, etc. You could have other mobs like cows, sheep, chicken-duck-things, etc, too. You could then stick them in an item frame to identify what you find in a stable or chest.

Oh, and you should be able to create a 2x1 bathtub by placing two Cauldrons side-by-side just like when you make a double chest. Making a tub out of hatches currently requires a 3x3 area for a 2x1 tub, and the bottom is often the roof of the floor below, so leaks! So annoying!

So, let me just say right at the beginning of this post that I'm essentially just massively expanding on the initial idea from the top of the page; which is why it's going to be bigger than the first post by an order of magnitude.

So, one of the most important things that Mojang tells us to do in these things is writing about the "how" of it being done; so here we go: any time that you are exploring a Mesa/Badlands biome or any of its various subtypes. And the train generation algorithm indicates you are due to find 4 or more separate abandoned mine shafts anywhere within 20 chunks of this chunk that is being loaded for the first time, it begins to rez-in a "mining town".

Mining towns are just a mesa/badlands village (Distinct from the dessert type, less of an Arabic/Pueblo feeling to the buildings, more "wild west boom town" with fence gates instead of normal doors on many buildings, for example) they are made primarily out of oak and, oddly, spruce wood, and oak trap-doors in place of glass for the windows. (Just as the updated dessert villages often don't use glass at all.) They have a weighty tendency to have forges/blacksmiths and smelter buildings instead of the usual suspects in terms of jobs for the villagers, and their "garden" plots follow advanced "player technology" patterns, using a single waterlogged spruce plank at the center of a 7-by-7 square of blank ground, surrounded by an oak fence.

There is a roughly 90% chance that such villages are zombie villages

I actually really like this one; it would give the Mesa/Badlands more character and history, while giving those who wish to settle there a base of operations. Maybe even instead of a well, it could force a mineshaft to generate directly to under the village with a cobblestone or gravel-filled shaft leading straight into the mine.

That’s a great idea! Saddles could spawn in loot chests along with raw gold ore. There could also be horses tied to poles via leads, to give the illusion the villagers left in a hurry not even bothering to take their horses. :)

It's a neat idea, but there are a few issues.

First, the idea of making real clouds to mix in with the insubstantial ones that have something interesting to explore is awesome.  However, a good number of people play with clouds off for various reasons, so these structures would stand out like sore thumbs instead of being hidden amongst the clouds.  Similarly, some people who don't currently play with clouds off would switch to doing so because they would be able to see the cloud structure more easily.

Another issue is lighting.  As it stands, you can't build any floating object without making a giant shadow underneath.  That would cause problems in two ways.  The first is they would be very obvious if you get close because there would be a giant black shadow on the ground.  The second is that giant black shadow would be a giant mob trap.  So they would need to figure out a way to have a big structure in the sky while also allowing the light to act like it isn't there.
Hope you guys have a great day! I sure am!

I like the idea.  The only problem is that if someone builds a house on the cloudline and a castle came along, it would potentially be worse than a charged creeper.

An alternative way to introduce cloud structures would be to add a cloud dimension. To enter this "Cloud Dimension", a portal frame needs to be built out of quartz blocks (activated with flint and steel, just like a nether portal), and its height needs to be above 192 Y. Inside the new dimension, there is no floor, only large clouds and cloud structures. Falling off a cloud could either kill you as the void does, or teleport you back to the overworld to fall to your doom.

"There currently aren't many structures that spawn above ground"

The underground has mineshafts, buried treasures, fossils, dungeons (which technically are not structures) and strongholds. By contrast, the surface the Overworld alone has villages, desert pyramids, jungle pyramids, swamp huts, igloos, pillager outposts, woodland mansions, shipwrecks, underwater ruins, and ocean monuments. And when writing this list, I had to check the wiki to make sure I didn't miss any. There is no shortage of above ground structures.

Also, the name sounds too much like End Cities.

Sails should be crafted like this, P means paper and W means wool:

P W P
W P W
P W P

I like this idea, but I would also like if you could add stationary balista for anti air weapons or use them to harpoon anything in the water and also cannons for attacking guys on land or at sea.  Also the engine turns the propeller.

Player controlled sailing ships could be interesting, but this seems like something that would require several new blocks plus actual in game construction to spawn, such as with the Iron Golem and Wither boss.

Suggested new blocks would be the Helm/Steering Wheel, Rudder, Mast, and Sail.

Restricting the hull construction to wood to match the Sunken Ships found in the Overworld, have them faster than the rowboat on forward speed, but slower on turn speed.

Biggest drawback I can see, is that the construction of such a ship would likely require a 5 wide and 9 long design to be able to hold a cabin/bed and a double chest cargo hold. (Not sure how large to suggest the ships as an entity would be)

Multiplayer benefit would be that 4 or 5 players could ride together(including the player at the helm) to places that are far from land. Having actual seats for the players, means the risk of multiple hostile mobs being able to board the ship, which could be a risk.
There should be sail mechanics too, more sails = faster, and the type of blocks you make the hull out of should affect how low the ship rides in the water, like the Davinci's vessels mod.
Multiplayer with ships sound awesome. I might even unironically call it EPIC.

I don't know if it's possible, but it would be fantastic if the Goop was non-newtonian like custard -

It would behave as if you always had frost-walker: when an player/non-slime-mob touches the top of the goop it spawns a lily-pad-like surface (just a thin shell that cannot be picked up even with silk touch) that de-spawns after about half a second, at which point anything on top of it falls in.
This would let you sprint across the top quickly with little to no penalty (maybe even bounce like a normal slime block if you fall in from above), but if you just walk you'll get about a block in before you sink.


I've been thinking a lot about slime variants, too, and one I particularly like the idea of is;

Fisher Slime -
A mostly-normal Slime, alongside the standard attack it can fire a string of slime to snare and reel-in targets as if using a fishing rod.

When idle, Fisher Slimes attempt to find blocks above water/goop sources. They rappel up to them and hang in wait for a target to come close enough to reel in, and only then jump down to begin attacking. While hanging they occasionally also drop a lure as per normal fishing: they hold (and digest) anything they catch.


I think this mob would very gel well with these goop ponds, especially if the slimes can swim freely in the goop (being hooked into the middle of one would be a nightmare).
It'd also be great if slimes moved slightly faster on slime-stone and could climb it freely (even hanging from the roof) for the same reason

Another idea to go with this:

Congealed Slime

Congealed slime is a display block that is functionally the same as an Armor Stand, but visually looks like a slime block with items floating inside. The slime-block is hidden when submerged in Goop.

They spawn in slime dens, most often in Goop, and generally hold one or two pieces of high-quality Armor and/or a Tool/Weapon. They sometimes spawn with one of the following: Bone, Arrow, Torch, Water Bottle, Emerald, Raw Metal, Shield, Name Tag, Potion, or Enchanted Book. They rarely include a Skeleton Head. The Congealed Slime has a few poses that are randomly picked from on spawn; unlike the Armor Stand the pieces may be broken apart as if they are individually floating.

Breaking the Congealed Slime without silk touch destroys the block.


- This gives you a reason to seek out these structures above and beyond the slime balls, and might tempt you to take a dip to retrieve another adventurer's loot.

Coming back to this with a thing that played on my mind last night:

Brine Pools

If we were to get Blue Slimes that live in or below oceans (like the tropical ones), it would be great to have a variant Slime Den that is based on real-life Brine Pools.

The Briny Goop would sit in a small depression at the bottom of the ocean - a lake under the sea - and, while no mobs would survive long in it other than slimes, mussels and various fish would spawn around the edge of it.
This idea is so good and Minecrafty, it would be great if it was just added as it is in this feedback.

Personally, I think that instead of adding the slime caves as a structure, it should be more of a biome. With the current new biome system, making the slime chunk an entire biome would makes much more sense and help improve on the caves. Not only that, they can spawn more often under swamp biomes so it makes sense lore wise

Although I think this is excessive, I do agree that slime-chunks are outdated, and feel like they should have been replaced with something that makes more sense. It doesn't make logical sense for slimes to just spawn in some random chunks, it feels like an unfinished feature. I also like the idea of slimeballs having more uses though, but goop and some of the other features are a little too much. Perhaps when it rains there is a chance for slimes to spawn anywhere in the world?
